H0.text: A base is what acidic hydrogen atoms will be transferred to.

H1.text: Water is the acceptor of acidic hydrogen atoms.

H2.text: A cup is the substance to which acidic hydrogen atoms are transferred.

H3.text: Another atom is the recipient to which acidic hydrogen atoms are transferred.

A4.text: In the Brønsted–Lowry model, a base is defined as a substance that accepts protons (acidic hydrogen atoms). For example, in the reaction where a water molecule donates an H+ to pyridine, the pyridine acts as the base by accepting the proton.

A5.text: In the dissociation of water (H2O + H2O ⇌ H3O+ + OH−), one water molecule acts as a base by accepting an H+ ion from another water molecule, forming the hydronium ion (H3O+).

A6.text: In aqueous solutions of Brønsted–Lowry acids, the hydrogen is transferred to H2O, forming hydronium (H3O+).

A7.text: In the Brønsted–Lowry model, a base is defined as a substance that accepts protons (acidic hydrogen atoms).
